title: Mulvane shows biblical works by once famous but nearly forgotten artist
text:
Mulvane shows biblical works by once famous but nearly forgotten artist 'Albert Bloch: Scenes from the Life of Christ' on display through Jan. 23 Posted: October 24, 2015 - 5:01pm Back | Next SUBMITTED In "The Rest on the Flight into Egypy," a circa 1930-32 oil paining on display through Jan. 23 in the exhibit "Albert Bloch: Scenes from the Life of Christ" at the Mulvane Art Museum on the campus of Washburn University, Bloch shows Mary and Joseph stopping to eat and sleep as refugees from King Herod's threats to murder the infant Jesus. Back | Next SUBMITTED In the 1926 oil painting "Gethsemane," Jesus prays in the garden at the foot of the Mount of Olives in Jerusalem after the Last Supper and before his arrest. The painting is part the exhibit "Albert Bloch: Scenes from the Life of Christ" on display through Jan. 23 at the Mulvane Art Museum on the campus of Washburn University. Back | Next ALBERT BLOCH FOUNDATION Albert Bloch paints in 1958 in the attic studio of his home at 1015 Alabama in Lawrence where he died March 23, 1961, after a long career as an artist and professor and head of the art department at the University of Kansas. Through Jan. 23, the Mulvane Art Museum is showing the exhibit "Albert Bloch: Scenes from the Life of Christ." Back | Next SUBMITTED In the 1936 watercolor "Parable," part of the Mulvane Art Museum's special exhibit "Albert Bloch: Scenes from the Life of Christ," the artist depicts Jesus's story of "The Widow's Offering" (Mark 12:4241-44 Luke 21:14). Back | Next SUBMITTED In in the 1953 oil painting "Apotheosis," one of the latest works in the Mulvane Art Museum's exhibit "Albert Bloch: Scenes from the Life of Christ," the artist visualizes his summary of humankind's spiritual yearning. BLOCH 
What: “Albert Bloch: Scenes from the Life of Christ” 
When: Through Jan. 23, with opening reception from 5:30 to 7:30 p.m. Friday, Nov. 6 
Where: Mulvane Art Museum, Washburn University, just south of the S.W. 17th and Jewell entrance to the campus 
Hours: 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. Tuesdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Wednesday through Friday, 1 to 4 p.m. Saturday, closes Sundays, Mondays and holidays

Admission: Free By Bill Blankenship bill.blankenship@cjonline.com 
Albert Bloch, creator of the works in “Albert Bloch: Scenes from the Life of Christ” on display through Jan. 23 at the Mulvane Art Museum, was a self-described “square peg.” 
Reinhild Janzen, Washburn University professor emerita of art history, who acted as guest curator for the exhibit, wrote in the show’s guide that Bloch was born in 1882 into a German-Jewish family in St. Louis, “then a predominantly Catholic city.” From 1909 to 1919, Bloch lived and worked in the largely Catholic city of Munich, Germany, where he became the only American to show with the highly influential Blue Rider group, which, Janzen wrote, “included modernist artists Franz Marc and Vassilly Kadinsky who sought to revitalize the spiritual in art.” 
Although the Blue Rider exhibitions were at the forefront of the development of modern art in Germany, Bloch never capitalized on his connection to it after returning to the United States in 1920 after the end of World War I. Bloch didn’t even include the Blue Rider group on his resume when he was hired in 1923 by the University of Kansas as a professor and head of its department of painting and drawing. 
Bloch also didn’t mount a commercial art exhibit after 1921. He chose instead to become independent from the art market and showed his work by invitation only. He taught at KU until his retirement in 1947, and he continued to live, paint and write poetry in Lawrence until his death in 1961. 
About his career decisions, Bloch is quoted as saying, “On the whole, I am an impossible creature, quite willing to remain an obscure, rough-hewn square peg, if only I may keep my inward freedom.” 
One of the subjects Bloch often explored in his art and poetry were narratives from the Bible, some of which are the subject of the Mulvane show. 
“Throughout five decades of artistic activity Bloch consistently turned to biblical themes,” Janzen wrote. “For him spiritual searching and genuine faith were a unifying force in his life and work. He kept a Bible at his bedside and marked it as he read in it. However, he never joined a church.” 
Janzen added, “Both in his writings and his art, he criticized the hypocrisy among professed believers of all denominations.” 
Rather than organize “Albert Bloch: Scenes from the Life of Christ” chronologically by when they were created, Janzen chose to arrange them in the sequence of the New Testament accounts of the life, death and resurrection of Jesus Christ, dividing them into four sections: “Christ’s Incarnation and Childhood,” “Christ’s Ministry,” “Christ’s Passion” and “The Resurrection of Christ.” 
“Bloch’s images are never mere illustrations of biblical themes, but interpretations of the existential affinity he felt for Christ’s prophetic words,” Janzen wrote. “As such they also allude to events in the artist’s personal life as well as those of the world and times he lived in, including the sufferings and devastation of World Wars I and II.” 
“Albert Bloch: Scenes from the Life of Christ” was built around three large religious paintings by Bloch given to the Mulvane Art Museum about 10 years ago by the brothers Gregory and Eric Voth of Topeka, whose father, Harold, collected Bloch paintings for more than 50 years. Other works in the exhibit come from the collection of a third Voth brother, Nicholas, and from the Albert Bloch Foundation of Kansas City, Mo., which was founded by the artist’s wife, Anna Bloch, who died in 2014 in Lawrence at the age of 101. 
Bloch’s contributions to the world of art were championed by his widow who reached out to the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art, which in 1997 mounted the retrospective exhibit “Albert Bloch: the American Blue Rider,” which also was shown at the Stadtische Galerie im Lenbachhause in Munich and the Delaware Art Museum in Wilmington. 
Bloch’s works also have been shown at the Spencer Museum at the University of Kansas, where scholars have researched and written about him. 
One of them is David Cateforis, a KU professor of art history, who has written several articles on Bloch and is co-curator of “Albert Bloch: Themes and Variations, Paintings and Watercolors from the Albert Bloch Foundation,” which is on display through Jan. 2 at the Lawrence Arts Center, 940 New Hampshire, Lawrence. 
In support of the Mulvane exhibit, Cateforis will present at 6 p.m. Nov. 10 a lecture on how Bloch would revisit a relatively small number of biblical themes during his career but alter his interpretations of them. 
Bloch’s poetry, specifically his epic poem, “Garden of Asses,” which tells the Christian story from Christ’s point of view, also will be explored. At 6 p.m. Dec. 1, selections from the poem will be read by Eric McHenry, assistant professor of English at Washburn University and the current poet laureate of Kansas, and Jeffrey Weinburg, a retired KU administrator and a painter with a long-standing interest in Bloch’s art and poetry. 
Janzen also will lead a tour of the exhibit and discuss it at 4 p.m. Jan. 20. 
More about the Mulvane Art Museum and its other current and forthcoming exhibits can be found at www.washburn.edu/mulvane .
